items.title: After Rocket Attack, an Israeli City Seems Resigned to More in the Future
items.abstract: Intense fighting with Gaza has heightened concerns about safety in Rishon LeZion and seems to have renewed the sentiment among residents of the unlikeliness of a long-term solution in their lifetimes.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Charting a Post-Pollution Path for Cities – From London, 1952, through Beijing, 2013
items.abstract: Facing epic smog, China charts a shift from coal to gas for Beijing, and beyond.

items.title: Police to Use Fake Pill Bottles to Track Drugstore Thieves
items.abstract: The New York Police Department says it will stock pharmacy shelves with decoy products that contain tracking devices.

items.title: Reveling in the Rites of the City
items.abstract: When the economist Jeffrey Sachs has a Sunday at home, he turns his focus to indigenous Gotham rites, like navigating Zabar’s.

items.title: A Boutique for the Great Outdoors and the Urban Wild
items.abstract: Snow Peak, newly opened in Manhattan, is more than a camping store.

items.title: N.Y.C.F.C.’s Patrick Vieira Acknowledges ‘Long Learning Process’
items.abstract: Introduced on Wednesday as New York City F.C.’s second head coach, Vieira, 39, was confident he would overcome his lack of coaching experience and unfamiliarity with M.L.S.
keywords: New York City Football Club (Soccer Team)

items.title: Airbnb Takes Its Case to U.S. Mayors Conference
items.abstract: Having tried to mobilize the public in its favor, Airbnb offers to collect $200 million in hotel taxes for cities.

items.title: New York City Officials Announce Efforts to Fight Zika Virus
items.abstract: With seven confirmed cases in the state, including three in the city, health administrators announced plans to prevent the virus from spreading.

items.title: Justin Peck Calmly Creates a Kingdom at City Ballet
items.abstract: “The Most Incredible Thing,” which debuts on Tuesday, is the 10th ballet Mr. Peck has choreographed for the company he joined in 2007.

items.title: This Super Bowl Is Not Everyone’s Bowl of Chips
items.abstract: St. Louis is angry the Rams left. New Orleans thinks the Saints got cheated. Los Angeles has the Rams, but hey, LeBron is back. Atlanta is the conflicted host.

items.title: How Bauhaus Redefined What Design Could Do for Society
items.abstract: A century after its founding, the German school of art and architecture remains one of the most transcendent — and frustrating — movements of the Modernist age.

items.title: We Need a National Rural Broadband Plan
items.abstract: The government has given a lot of money to major telecommunications companies without much regulatory accountability.

items.title: Lagos, City of Hustle, Builds an Art ‘Ecosystem’
items.abstract: West Africa’s new art destination is a sprawling megacity with a generation of artists, gallerists and collectors powering the scene.

items.title: Katy Perry Pulls Shoes Resembling Blackface: ‘Our Intention Was Never to Inflict Any Pain’
items.abstract: By removing the shoes, some of which featured large red lips on a black field, the singer’s fashion line became the latest brand to back away from products stirring offense.

items.title: Why a Blue City Is Feeling the Blues
items.abstract: New York is paying a price for Wall Street’s economic dominance.

items.title: How a Boy in Rural Iceland Became a Tool for Global Fascism
items.abstract: “Red Milk,” a novel by Sjón, examines a young man’s path to neo-Nazism.

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

items.title: After Urban Flight, Corporate Campuses Add a Taste of the City
items.abstract: Suburban headquarters are being redesigned to add more amenities that will integrate better with their communities and attract the skilled workers.

items.title: Could Detroit Become the Next Fashion City?
items.abstract: In bringing an exhibition of creative talent to New York, the fashion label Deviate wants to show that Detroit has more to offer than a quick hit of novelty for luxury giants.
